Ã‚Â Ã¢â‚¬Â¨Alicia Silverstone is an actress who rose to stardom with her leading role in the 1995 sleeper hit, Clueless. Her many other acting credits include leading roles in Batman films, God Behaving Badly, and Excess Baggage. In 2011, MenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Health voted Alicia one of the 100 hottest women of all time.
A long-time food and animal rights activist, and a passionate environmentalist, Alicia is author of the #1 NY Times bestseller, The Kind Diet, and founder of TheKindLife.com.
Get her loving and inspiring insights on how to lean into a life that is kind to your body, your conscience, and your planet. Find out more about AliciaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s work by clicking here.

******************************************Ã¢â‚¬Â¨The response to the Food Revolution Summit has been extraordinary. More than 110,000 signed up, and letters of appreciation have been pouring in from all over the world.

When? You can stream the ENTIRE Food Revolution Summit on demand, for no charge all day Friday May 9th, Saturday May 10th, and Sunday May 11th. For the next three days, you can get free access to gamechanging must-have insights from an all-star team of food movement luminaries, all interviewed by my dad and colleague, John Robbins.
ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s all available now, complimentary, on demand Ã¢â‚¬â€œ three days of unlimited listening.

You can get breakthrough insights from Dr. Mark Hyman, Dr. Neal Barnard, Dr. Robert Lustig, JJ Virgin, Dr. Dean Ornish, Andrew Kimbrell, Jane Goodall, Woody Harrelson, Amy Goodman, Vani Hari (Food Babe), Dr. Caldwell Esselstyn, Dr. T. Colin Campbell, and 12 more amazing food leaders.
Our summits have reached more than a quarter million people, but weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve never done this before. The demand for this information this year has been so powerful that we felt compelled to extend the opportunity.
That means you can join in, and get it all, for no charge. But hurry, because the Encore Weekend only lasts until Sunday. So dive in now, and get it all.
Yours for a healthy future,
Ocean Robbins http://foodrevolutionsummit.org/broadcasts/day1/

Ã¢â‚¬ËœSymphony of the Soil,Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ a Salute to What Feeds Us New York Times, Published: October 10, 2013
Unlike many recent documentaries about our careless stewardship of the planet, Deborah Koons GarciaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ã¢â‚¬Å“Symphony of the SoilÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t feel like a rap on the knuckles. Unfolding with gentle joy and an unexpected beauty, this ode to the miracle of the EarthÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s topmost layer gives us a newfound respect for the ground beneath our feet.
Filming on four continents and with contributions from impassioned scientists, farmers and foodies, Ms. Garcia explains how dead dirt is transformed into living soil Ã¢â‚¬â€ and, perhaps more important, how many of our farming practices are effecting the reverse. But this isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t simply another plea for sustainable agriculture and the rejection of herbicides; celebration, not disapproval, is Ms. GarciaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s default tone.
Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Times Square on New YearÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Eve all the time in the soil,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ the soil biologist Dr. Elaine Ingham says enthusiastically, and, with the help of a microscope, we see exactly what she means. And when images of parched earth and desiccated corn make us anxious, we can luxuriate in the fabulous hair and poetic flourishes of the microbial ecologist Dr. Ignacio Chapela, whose crooning homage to the Ã¢â‚¬Å“dialogue of nutrientsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ between soil and water belongs on everyoneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s meditation mixtape.
Infused with an infectious love for its subject, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Symphony of the SoilÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ presents a wondrous world of critters and bacteria, mulch and manure. Maintaining this layer in all its richness and diversity is, the film argues, perhaps our most critical weapon against climate change. At the very least, you will leave with the profound understanding that feeding our soil is the first step in feeding ourselves. <a href="
http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/11/movies/symphony-of-the-soil-a-salute-to-what-" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
